description: The implementation of a Best Practices Service Management Framework will deliver tangible benefits to all organizations of any size. This mini series explores the benefits of implementing a service management framework, including ROI realized by sample organizations. We also explore the ITIL framework; the most adopted ITSM framework globally.
descriptionMD: The implementation of a Best Practices Service Management Framework will deliver tangible benefits to all organizations of any size. This mini series explores the benefits of implementing a service management framework, including ROI realized by sample organizations. We also explore the ITIL framework; the most adopted ITSM framework globally.
name: ITIL Executive Overview
subtitle: Benefits of a Service Management Framework

episodes.description: This 2-parter gives looks at the common complaints that businesses have with IT and the reasons for implementing an IT Service Management framework. In the 2nd episode we explore the numbers behind the benefits that have been reaslised by organisations of varying sizes globally.
episodes.title: Benefits of Service Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.220
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.220 --> 00:00:03.505
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.505 --> 00:00:06.282
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.282 --> 00:00:08.243
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.243 --> 00:00:11.857
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.857 --> 00:00:14.330
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.330 --> 00:00:16.760
Helping you learn everywhere you go.

8
00:00:16.760 --> 00:00:21.270
I'm your host, Zach Memos, for
this episode of ITIL Executive Overview.

9
00:00:21.270 --> 00:00:23.990
Benefits of Service Management
is the name of this episode,

10
00:00:23.990 --> 00:00:27.595
let's find out more from
our expert Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:27.595 --> 00:00:33.430
>> [LAUGH] Well, there's an introduction,
yeah that was a scary introduction.

12
00:00:33.430 --> 00:00:34.488
Zach, how are you?

13
00:00:34.488 --> 00:00:35.530
>> Good, doing great.

14
00:00:35.530 --> 00:00:39.870
And this is very exciting,
beginning of a little miniseries here.

15
00:00:39.870 --> 00:00:44.829
>> Yeah, normally when we are in
a sort of a classroom environment, for

16
00:00:44.829 --> 00:00:48.080
instance, then we would quite often get,
or

17
00:00:48.080 --> 00:00:54.360
I would quite often get asked to
provide overviews for executive levels.

18
00:00:54.360 --> 00:00:57.940
People that didn't necessarily wanna
go on an ITIL foundation course.

19
00:00:57.940 --> 00:00:58.881
>> Right.
>> Or people that,

20
00:00:58.881 --> 00:01:00.740
because I mean that's a three day course.

21
00:01:00.740 --> 00:01:04.040
That's a three day class, they didn't
necessarily want the accreditation.

22
00:01:04.040 --> 00:01:08.860
But also they want to understand more
about what the benefits of ITIL are, and

23
00:01:08.860 --> 00:01:12.750
what the benefits of implementing
a service management framework are.

24
00:01:12.750 --> 00:01:17.020
So really, the intention of
this particular series is to,

25
00:01:17.020 --> 00:01:20.140
and it is a very short series so
we can call it a miniseries,

26
00:01:20.140 --> 00:01:24.670
is just to really go over what we would
normally do in an executive overview,

27
00:01:24.670 --> 00:01:27.530
which is take a look a the benefits
of service management.

28
00:01:27.530 --> 00:01:31.480
And I don't just mean sort of
the hypothetical benefits.

29
00:01:31.480 --> 00:01:33.370
I don't mean the theoretical benefits.

30
00:01:33.370 --> 00:01:36.940
What I actually mean
are the tangible benefits as well.

31
00:01:36.940 --> 00:01:42.020
What you expect to achieve by or
the benefits

32
00:01:42.020 --> 00:01:46.380
you expect to realize by implementing
the service management framework.

33
00:01:46.380 --> 00:01:49.075
And so that's what I wanted to
do in this particular series.

34
00:01:49.075 --> 00:01:50.935
>> And
that's the takeaway from this course.

35
00:01:50.935 --> 00:01:56.855
>> Well not just that, but it's also
a look at sort of ITIL as a framework.

36
00:01:56.855 --> 00:01:59.795
>> Okay.
>> So in our first episode we're going to

37
00:01:59.795 --> 00:02:04.215
review the actual tangible benefits
from implementing the service

38
00:02:04.215 --> 00:02:05.725
management framework.

39
00:02:05.725 --> 00:02:07.412
And then in our subsequent episodes,

40
00:02:07.412 --> 00:02:11.010
we're just going to look at the ITIL
framework in a little bit more depth.

41
00:02:11.010 --> 00:02:12.960
>> Okay.
>> We're not going to go to the depth

42
00:02:12.960 --> 00:02:18.210
that's needed for an ITIL foundation
class, because obviously we've got an ITIL

43
00:02:18.210 --> 00:02:23.400
foundation series and we really don't need
to repeat all of that, but we are aware.

44
00:02:24.450 --> 00:02:28.710
And I'm perfectly aware because
of the queries that I get,

45
00:02:28.710 --> 00:02:33.150
that there are those out there that don't
necessarily want to take an accredited

46
00:02:33.150 --> 00:02:38.290
class but that simply want to have
an understanding of ITIL itself.

47
00:02:38.290 --> 00:02:39.990
>> Right.
>> And so for

48
00:02:39.990 --> 00:02:44.240
the first part of this particular series
we're going to be looking at benefits, and

49
00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:47.840
then in the second part of this
series we're gonna spend some time,

50
00:02:47.840 --> 00:02:52.510
a few episodes, just looking at
our ITIL processes themselves.

51
00:02:52.510 --> 00:02:55.180
>> Wonderful.
>> And just a really quick recap over

52
00:02:55.180 --> 00:02:58.230
what those processes are,
just a synopsis of ITIL.

53
00:02:58.230 --> 00:02:58.920
>> Fantastic.

54
00:02:58.920 --> 00:03:01.020
>> But when I talk about the benefits,

55
00:03:01.020 --> 00:03:03.680
I'm not just talking about
the benefits of ITIL though.

56
00:03:03.680 --> 00:03:07.659
And I think that's something that
I kind of want to make clear

57
00:03:07.659 --> 00:03:12.810
right at the very start, we are not
talking about benefits of just ITIL.

58
00:03:12.810 --> 00:03:18.390
We're talking about the benefits of
a structured service management framework.

59
00:03:18.390 --> 00:03:19.450
>> Okay.

60
00:03:19.450 --> 00:03:22.268
>> What do you know about
the difference between or

61
00:03:22.268 --> 00:03:26.574
the relationship between service
management and project management?

62
00:03:26.574 --> 00:03:29.085
[LAUGH] This is called putting
him on the spot, right.

63
00:03:29.085 --> 00:03:32.452
[LAUGH]
>> Jo, I'm gonna defer to you on this one.

64
00:03:32.452 --> 00:03:35.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know that you know more than I.

65
00:03:35.670 --> 00:03:41.790
>> Well the reason that I ask is because
there is an overlap between the two,

66
00:03:41.790 --> 00:03:43.640
and we call that dev ops.

67
00:03:43.640 --> 00:03:48.330
We call that service transition, and we'll
take a look at it in a subsequent episode.

68
00:03:48.330 --> 00:03:51.655
But there is, as I said,
there is an overlap.

69
00:03:51.655 --> 00:03:55.790
But project management are responsible for
creating new services.

70
00:03:55.790 --> 00:04:00.145
They are responsible for
designing and developing and

71
00:04:00.145 --> 00:04:04.695
then deploying new services
into the live environment.

72
00:04:04.695 --> 00:04:05.929
And service management,

73
00:04:05.929 --> 00:04:09.019
well I like to think of service
management as the book end to that.

74
00:04:09.019 --> 00:04:13.196
Service management are the people that
actually take a look at the strategy,

75
00:04:13.196 --> 00:04:16.340
they come up with the ideas for
the new services.

76
00:04:16.340 --> 00:04:20.499
But then what they'll also do, they'll
hand that over to project management and

77
00:04:20.499 --> 00:04:23.405
project management design and
develop and then deploy.

78
00:04:23.405 --> 00:04:28.280
And then service management pick up
the new service and then they run it

79
00:04:28.280 --> 00:04:33.250
as part of business as usual,
as part of the operational perspective.

80
00:04:33.250 --> 00:04:38.190
So what we're going to be doing in
this particular series is we're going

81
00:04:38.190 --> 00:04:41.750
to be just taking a look at
the operational side of things, so

82
00:04:41.750 --> 00:04:44.200
the business as usual side of things.

83
00:04:44.200 --> 00:04:47.420
Now there is gonna be some
overlap into project management.

84
00:04:47.420 --> 00:04:52.656
And in fact there's actually going to be
some tenderals into project management

85
00:04:52.656 --> 00:04:57.597
where we might not have the project
management guys pick up certain things.

86
00:04:57.597 --> 00:05:00.383
And we might say, well look,
that still needs to happen.

87
00:05:00.383 --> 00:05:04.257
And so because it still needs to happen,
it's gonna happen at this point in time.

88
00:05:04.257 --> 00:05:08.790
But we're going to do it at the same time
that the project guys are going to do it.

89
00:05:08.790 --> 00:05:12.350
Or we might ask the project
guys do it own our behalf.

90
00:05:13.960 --> 00:05:17.380
So there is a synergy between the two.

91
00:05:17.380 --> 00:05:22.350
I expect there to be teamwork,
I expect it.

92
00:05:22.350 --> 00:05:28.280
If there's not,
then we've got a very disjointed IT team.

93
00:05:30.250 --> 00:05:34.390
And I have to say, and I am gonna say
this, that that's actually quite common.

94
00:05:34.390 --> 00:05:40.420
That's not an unusual to have an IT team
that consists of two distinct sides.

95
00:05:40.420 --> 00:05:44.171
And I hear this all the time,
where we've got project team and

96
00:05:44.171 --> 00:05:49.280
the development guys, and then we have
got the service operation guys and

97
00:05:49.280 --> 00:05:53.380
the business as usual guys, and they're
the support guys as they're called.

98
00:05:53.380 --> 00:05:56.780
So the project guys build something and
then they kind of throw it over the wall

99
00:05:56.780 --> 00:05:59.840
to the support guys, and the support guys
have got to deal with it afterwards.

100
00:06:01.940 --> 00:06:03.220
Yeah, that's not exactly how you want it.
>> Not ideal.

101
00:06:03.220 --> 00:06:08.210
>> No, what we want is a cohesive
IT structure, that's what we want.

102
00:06:08.210 --> 00:06:10.570
We want collaboration between the two.

103
00:06:10.570 --> 00:06:15.320
And in an ideal world there
shouldn't be a barrier between them.

104
00:06:15.320 --> 00:06:18.830
They shouldn't be two separate teams.

105
00:06:18.830 --> 00:06:23.451
They should be two cohesive teams that
collaborate on not just on projects but

106
00:06:23.451 --> 00:06:25.242
also on support work as well.

107
00:06:25.242 --> 00:06:27.540
>> Okay.
>> And that's what we're aiming for.

108
00:06:27.540 --> 00:06:31.270
And if we have service management and
project management implemented and

109
00:06:31.270 --> 00:06:33.350
we have a framework for both, and

110
00:06:33.350 --> 00:06:36.090
you'll actually find that that does
work and it works really well.

111
00:06:36.090 --> 00:06:39.140
But it also saves us money.

112
00:06:39.140 --> 00:06:41.840
Let's face it,
that's what everybody wants, right.

113
00:06:41.840 --> 00:06:42.675
>> I wanna make money.

114
00:06:42.675 --> 00:06:44.620
>> [LAUGH]
>> Save money, ain't gonna happen.

115
00:06:44.620 --> 00:06:45.536
Make money.
[LAUGH]

116
00:06:45.536 --> 00:06:47.670
>> [LAUGH] No Zach, you wanna save money.

117
00:06:47.670 --> 00:06:48.580
>> I wanna save money.

118
00:06:48.580 --> 00:06:50.110
>> Yes you do.

119
00:06:50.110 --> 00:06:51.760
>> She's right.
>> Let's take a look at some common

120
00:06:51.760 --> 00:06:53.120
complaints for IT.

121
00:06:53.120 --> 00:06:56.570
Because what I'm really doing here
is looking at the justification for

122
00:06:56.570 --> 00:06:57.960
service management.

123
00:06:57.960 --> 00:07:01.960
Not just ITIL,
we're talking about things like SIAM and

124
00:07:01.960 --> 00:07:03.910
we're also talking about
[INAUDIBLE] as well.

125
00:07:03.910 --> 00:07:06.270
There are other service
management frameworks out there.

126
00:07:06.270 --> 00:07:11.840
And of course we already have, at the time
of recording, we have a SIAM series.

127
00:07:11.840 --> 00:07:16.162
We are currently in production
with a series as well.

128
00:07:16.162 --> 00:07:22.510
So we are involved with all of the service
management frameworks and not just ITIL.

129
00:07:22.510 --> 00:07:25.510
But these are common
complaints across the world,

130
00:07:25.510 --> 00:07:28.160
around the world, just general complaints.

131
00:07:28.160 --> 00:07:31.860
If you think about, and this is just
sort of market research, by the way.

132
00:07:31.860 --> 00:07:34.920
This is not something that
we have done ourselves.

133
00:07:34.920 --> 00:07:39.870
We've taken our information from
places like Gartner and Forrester.

134
00:07:39.870 --> 00:07:41.619
This is just general market research.

135
00:07:41.619 --> 00:07:46.408
Do you know that 21% of our organizations,
just companies in general,

136
00:07:46.408 --> 00:07:49.224
view IT as an expensive overhead?

137
00:07:49.224 --> 00:07:50.502
>> Certainly.

138
00:07:50.502 --> 00:07:53.240
I would have thought it would
be even higher than that.

139
00:07:53.240 --> 00:07:54.030
>> Yeah, it's only 21%.

140
00:07:54.030 --> 00:07:56.652
>> Yeah.
>> I think a lot of organizations now,

141
00:07:56.652 --> 00:08:00.680
if we were to turn the clock back
to when ITIL first started, so

142
00:08:00.680 --> 00:08:02.313
over 20 years ago now.

143
00:08:02.313 --> 00:08:03.361
>> Way back in the day.

144
00:08:03.361 --> 00:08:07.150
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, when that first started,
it would've been more than that.

145
00:08:07.150 --> 00:08:12.050
But now we recognize that IT is
an integrated part of our industry.

146
00:08:12.050 --> 00:08:16.218
But nevertheless, they're still 21%, so
that's still quite high given that you're

147
00:08:16.218 --> 00:08:19.791
talking about the generation of people
that cannot leave their cell phones for

148
00:08:19.791 --> 00:08:21.720
longer than five minutes.

149
00:08:21.720 --> 00:08:26.107
Right, and yet still 21% of people
think that it's just an overhead,

150
00:08:26.107 --> 00:08:27.466
that's quite scary.

151
00:08:27.466 --> 00:08:31.571
And only 45% of people consider IT,
that's the IT team,

152
00:08:31.571 --> 00:08:35.619
to be necessary because they-
>> Thought that number would be higher

153
00:08:35.619 --> 00:08:36.136
as well.

154
00:08:36.136 --> 00:08:40.577
>> Well, no, I mean, I would have thought,
well, actually, yes, you're right.

155
00:08:40.577 --> 00:08:43.951
Because if only 45% consider
IT to be necessary, I mean,

156
00:08:43.951 --> 00:08:47.335
we need IT to do absolutely
everything in our organization.

157
00:08:47.335 --> 00:08:48.697
>> To do absolutely everything.

158
00:08:48.697 --> 00:08:53.750
>> You can't get into
our building without IT.

159
00:08:53.750 --> 00:08:57.884
You can't get through a door,
probably in your building, without IT.

160
00:08:57.884 --> 00:09:02.757
You can't do anything without IT,
IT sends and receives email,

161
00:09:02.757 --> 00:09:04.978
IT sends and receives texts.

162
00:09:04.978 --> 00:09:07.368
It's IT that sends and
receives or makes and

163
00:09:07.368 --> 00:09:11.450
receives a phone call now because it's
all VOIP, it's all voice over IP.

164
00:09:12.730 --> 00:09:17.737
So when you consider that IT is part
of absolutely everything that we do,

165
00:09:17.737 --> 00:09:22.024
and yet only 45% of organizations
think that they need it.

166
00:09:22.024 --> 00:09:22.685
>> It's baffling.

167
00:09:22.685 --> 00:09:28.890
>> [LAUGH] No, we all need it,
and 100% of organizations use it.

168
00:09:28.890 --> 00:09:32.921
What about, 32% of business users
see IT as a valued partner?

169
00:09:32.921 --> 00:09:37.640
That means that the rest of them see
IT as something other than valued.

170
00:09:37.640 --> 00:09:39.213
>> Like an errant cousin or something?

171
00:09:39.213 --> 00:09:43.556
>> Right [LAUGH] or even as a partner,
I mean, consider this.

172
00:09:43.556 --> 00:09:48.575
Because IT is, well,
it's a partnership with the organization,

173
00:09:48.575 --> 00:09:54.751
and yet there's only 32% of business
users, that's people like you and Zach.

174
00:09:54.751 --> 00:09:58.806
Only 32% of people consider
IT to be valuable.

175
00:09:58.806 --> 00:10:04.119
That's, yeah, and
37% of business users perceive that

176
00:10:04.119 --> 00:10:09.128
what we do in IT is lay down the law,
that's what it says.

177
00:10:09.128 --> 00:10:11.439
>> [LAUGH]
>> What we do is constrain it,

178
00:10:11.439 --> 00:10:12.539
that's what we do.

179
00:10:12.539 --> 00:10:17.307
And if it wasn't for the the IT team,
we'd be able to do whatever we wanted,

180
00:10:17.307 --> 00:10:19.853
which is great, but there'd be chaos.

181
00:10:19.853 --> 00:10:21.920
But they don't perceive the value in that.

182
00:10:21.920 --> 00:10:26.235
They think that we constrain, and
they don't understand why we constrain.

183
00:10:26.235 --> 00:10:29.327
And a lot of this is down to
miscommunication, by the way.

184
00:10:29.327 --> 00:10:33.546
And again, that's something else
that is really something we

185
00:10:33.546 --> 00:10:37.935
can address by implementing
the service management framework.

186
00:10:39.410 --> 00:10:43.228
And 14% of organizations, this is
quite low compared to the others, and

187
00:10:43.228 --> 00:10:47.000
I'm kind of impressed by this, but
then I'm not, because it worries me.

188
00:10:47.000 --> 00:10:54.070
14% of organizations do not consider IT
to be necessary for business advancement.

189
00:10:54.070 --> 00:10:56.782
In other words,
we could have grown without IT.

190
00:10:56.782 --> 00:11:00.395
>> Yeah, we're talking about the guy
that sells brownies on the corner here,

191
00:11:00.395 --> 00:11:01.136
I think [LAUGH].

192
00:11:01.136 --> 00:11:04.490
>> Well, I don't know,
because even he needs IT now.

193
00:11:04.490 --> 00:11:06.219
>> No, I believe that, eveybody does.

194
00:11:06.219 --> 00:11:09.830
>> Because if you're selling brownies,
let's just take him.

195
00:11:09.830 --> 00:11:12.718
Let's say that here in the US,
for instance,

196
00:11:12.718 --> 00:11:17.917
if you're selling brownies in the corner,
then you're making money out of that.

197
00:11:17.917 --> 00:11:20.860
And that means that you've
gotta pay taxes on that money.

198
00:11:20.860 --> 00:11:23.035
Guess how you pay your taxes?

199
00:11:23.035 --> 00:11:29.960
You have to do this in IT,
you have to get on to the tax service.

200
00:11:29.960 --> 00:11:34.284
Whether it's HMRC, whether it's the IRS,
no matter who it is.

201
00:11:34.284 --> 00:11:40.190
Your tax organization, your tax
department, you've gotta file your taxes.

202
00:11:40.190 --> 00:11:43.594
So to turn around and say that even
the guy, that's probably the guy on

203
00:11:43.594 --> 00:11:47.536
the street corner selling brownies, well,
the fact is that he needs IT as well.

204
00:11:47.536 --> 00:11:51.090
And you can't tell me that
he doesn't have a cellphone.

205
00:11:51.090 --> 00:11:54.407
>> Right, that and also,
unless he's on social media,

206
00:11:54.407 --> 00:11:59.037
he's missing a huge portion of the market,
he could be reaching millions.

207
00:11:59.037 --> 00:12:00.849
>> Right, right, and yet

208
00:12:00.849 --> 00:12:06.970
14% of organizations don't consider
that they need IT to advance.

209
00:12:06.970 --> 00:12:08.640
>> That's crazy.
>> That's still a huge amount, I mean,

210
00:12:08.640 --> 00:12:11.304
I know it's lower than the rest,
but it's still a huge amount.

211
00:12:11.304 --> 00:12:13.314
>> It is, it is.

212
00:12:13.314 --> 00:12:15.785
>> So I want to sort of point out here,

213
00:12:15.785 --> 00:12:20.320
we've got the stated benefit
of implementing best practice.

214
00:12:20.320 --> 00:12:23.706
And what that means is,
in the ITIL publications,

215
00:12:23.706 --> 00:12:25.570
and we'll talk about
them in a little while.

216
00:12:25.570 --> 00:12:29.910
But in the ITIL publications,
we have stated benefits.

217
00:12:29.910 --> 00:12:34.751
In other words, they say well,
what we do in a service management

218
00:12:34.751 --> 00:12:38.107
framework is provide
value to the business.

219
00:12:38.107 --> 00:12:41.120
Zach knows something about value,
what do you know about value, Zach?

220
00:12:42.330 --> 00:12:43.265
>> Value is perceived.

221
00:12:43.265 --> 00:12:44.479
>> Right, okay-
>> But

222
00:12:44.479 --> 00:12:47.058
you didn't think I was gonna
do that did you [LAUGH]?

223
00:12:47.058 --> 00:12:52.310
>> No, I was hoping you were, I didn't
actually set him up for this, so I'm glad.

224
00:12:52.310 --> 00:12:56.164
I didn't prepare him for
this, but value is perceived.

225
00:12:56.164 --> 00:12:58.859
One of the things that we miss out in IT,

226
00:12:58.859 --> 00:13:04.820
we're not very good at selling ourselves
in IT, by the way, did you know that?

227
00:13:04.820 --> 00:13:06.113
>> Yeah, I imagined so.

228
00:13:06.113 --> 00:13:09.959
>> We're not,
we tend to be the kind of people, I mean,

229
00:13:09.959 --> 00:13:14.170
you've seen that just looking
at the previous slide.

230
00:13:14.170 --> 00:13:18.259
We tend to be the departments and
the teams that will just sort of sit in

231
00:13:18.259 --> 00:13:21.163
the corner and
just quietly get on with our work.

232
00:13:21.163 --> 00:13:25.234
And we're not very good at selling
ourselves, we're not very good at saying,

233
00:13:25.234 --> 00:13:28.450
this is what we've achieved,
this is what we've done.

234
00:13:28.450 --> 00:13:32.064
And because of us,
you have been to achieve this.

235
00:13:32.064 --> 00:13:35.199
We don't do that, we just wait for
them to ask us for something, and

236
00:13:35.199 --> 00:13:39.160
then we tend to give it to them and say,
there you go, that's what you asked for.

237
00:13:39.160 --> 00:13:43.350
Or, no, you can't have what you asked for,
but we've given you this instead.

238
00:13:43.350 --> 00:13:48.273
And we're not very good at sort of
articulating why it's been like that.

239
00:13:48.273 --> 00:13:50.353
We're really not good at that, so

240
00:13:50.353 --> 00:13:55.088
when we talk about providing value in
the form of goods or services, you will be

241
00:13:55.088 --> 00:13:59.280
amazed by how many organizations
don't appreciate the value of IT.

242
00:13:59.280 --> 00:14:02.640
And it's simply because
we're just not very good at

243
00:14:02.640 --> 00:14:04.580
articulating how valuable we are.

244
00:14:06.200 --> 00:14:11.582
We should be in a position where we
integrate IT with the business strategy.

245
00:14:11.582 --> 00:14:15.542
In other words, whatever the business
is decided is a strategy,

246
00:14:15.542 --> 00:14:19.430
then IT shouldn't be running,
behind picking up the pieces and

247
00:14:19.430 --> 00:14:23.120
trying to catch up,
IT should be leading that now.

248
00:14:23.120 --> 00:14:26.364
Like I've said, without IT,
you can't even get through the front door.

249
00:14:26.364 --> 00:14:31.810
So IT should be leading the strategy,
they should be driving the strategy.

250
00:14:31.810 --> 00:14:37.240
And in fact, they should be the ones that
sit in on the board of any organization

251
00:14:37.240 --> 00:14:41.840
and say, hey look, we've got this new
technology, we can do this for you.

252
00:14:43.400 --> 00:14:47.620
What we're also able to do, by the way
with implementing best practice,

253
00:14:47.620 --> 00:14:50.245
is with a framework, we can control cost.

254
00:14:50.245 --> 00:14:56.320
A lot of IT organizations,
a lot of IT departments,

255
00:14:56.320 --> 00:14:59.590
for instance, that, and
we call them service providers in ITIL.

256
00:14:59.590 --> 00:15:05.480
But there are a lot of IT departments
that don't really have a good handle,

257
00:15:05.480 --> 00:15:08.070
should I say, on cost.

258
00:15:08.070 --> 00:15:11.764
How much money is being spent and
where it's being spent.

259
00:15:11.764 --> 00:15:15.576
And what we do is,
we take a budget from the organization and

260
00:15:15.576 --> 00:15:19.720
we're actually seen as a cost
center to the organization.

261
00:15:19.720 --> 00:15:25.050
When in fact, if we can demonstrate
that we are delivering value,

262
00:15:25.050 --> 00:15:28.393
then we should be seen as a profit center.

263
00:15:28.393 --> 00:15:32.959
So a lot of implementing service
management allows you to

264
00:15:32.959 --> 00:15:38.100
take the cost center, and
turn that into a profit center.

265
00:15:38.100 --> 00:15:42.150
So we're no longer just a cost,
we're no longer a drain on the budget, but

266
00:15:42.150 --> 00:15:46.610
we're actually seen as driving
a profit for the organization.

267
00:15:47.850 --> 00:15:53.646
It's a huge change in perspective, that's
what we should be aiming to achieve,

268
00:15:53.646 --> 00:15:58.266
and that's what you can achieve
by implementing best practice,

269
00:15:58.266 --> 00:16:00.455
as well as management of risk.

270
00:16:00.455 --> 00:16:04.961
It's all about implementing efficient and
effective processes.

271
00:16:04.961 --> 00:16:11.485
Now efficiency means Doing it
right the first time, by golly.

272
00:16:11.485 --> 00:16:16.120
>> [LAUGH] No, it doesn't, we talked
about this, Zach, you know we have.

273
00:16:16.120 --> 00:16:18.045
And not just prior to this
particular episode, but

274
00:16:18.045 --> 00:16:19.447
we have talked about this at length.

275
00:16:19.447 --> 00:16:21.810
And efficiency means minimal waste.

276
00:16:23.270 --> 00:16:28.105
And in service management terms,
it means achieving an outcome,

277
00:16:28.105 --> 00:16:31.918
that's being effected with well,
minimal waste.

278
00:16:31.918 --> 00:16:36.170
Minimal waste in terms of time, so
as quickly as you possibly can.

279
00:16:36.170 --> 00:16:40.930
Minimal waste in terms of money,
as cheaply as you possibly can.

280
00:16:40.930 --> 00:16:42.870
But minimal waste in terms of scale,

281
00:16:45.010 --> 00:16:47.260
finding the right person
to do the right job.

282
00:16:47.260 --> 00:16:50.450
>> Which is exactly what I meant
by doing it right the first time.

283
00:16:50.450 --> 00:16:55.620
>> Did you know that having somebody
overskilled doing a particular job

284
00:16:55.620 --> 00:16:59.760
is just as inefficient as having
somebody who is underskilled.

285
00:17:01.130 --> 00:17:02.710
>> Yes, we talked about that before.

286
00:17:02.710 --> 00:17:05.630
>> We have talked about this
before in one of our other series.

287
00:17:05.630 --> 00:17:07.440
We have talked about this.

288
00:17:07.440 --> 00:17:09.950
Because the person that is overskilled

289
00:17:09.950 --> 00:17:14.140
is generally not going to be giving
100% to that particular task at hand.

290
00:17:14.140 --> 00:17:17.920
They're probably gonna be distracted,
I can do this with my eyes closed.

291
00:17:17.920 --> 00:17:20.070
They're gonna be distracted.

292
00:17:20.070 --> 00:17:22.990
Whereas the person that's
underskilled at least is going to be

293
00:17:24.620 --> 00:17:27.450
trying to deliver 100%.

294
00:17:27.450 --> 00:17:29.840
Now, nevertheless they're
going to be slightly

295
00:17:31.140 --> 00:17:36.120
behind in terms of productivity because
they need the necessary skills.

296
00:17:36.120 --> 00:17:39.260
But the person that's overskilled
is going to miss things as well.

297
00:17:39.260 --> 00:17:40.010
They're not gonna give 100%.

298
00:17:40.010 --> 00:17:44.190
So either one are just as
inefficient as the other.

299
00:17:44.190 --> 00:17:48.130
So we need to have somebody who has
the right skill level to do the right

300
00:17:48.130 --> 00:17:48.810
activity.

301
00:17:48.810 --> 00:17:52.320
>> Like the age old expression,
overqualified.

302
00:17:52.320 --> 00:17:56.570
>> Right, yeah, it's really dangerous
to have somebody that's overqualified.

303
00:17:56.570 --> 00:17:58.660
You might think that it's a great idea,
but it's not.

304
00:17:58.660 --> 00:18:01.050
They're gonna get bored very, very easily
and they're not going to give you 100%.

305
00:18:01.050 --> 00:18:05.080
So we talk about efficient and
effective processes.

306
00:18:05.080 --> 00:18:10.640
And effective processes means actually
doing what it's suppose to do and

307
00:18:10.640 --> 00:18:13.830
delivering the output that
it's suppose to deliver.

308
00:18:13.830 --> 00:18:17.480
We want to have continual
improvement embedded into

309
00:18:17.480 --> 00:18:20.450
sort of the business as usual,
and in normal operations.

310
00:18:20.450 --> 00:18:24.300
Continual improvement means that
we continually, in other words,

311
00:18:24.300 --> 00:18:28.350
on a regular basis,
it's an iterative approach.

312
00:18:28.350 --> 00:18:32.130
We have an iterative
approach to assessing and

313
00:18:32.130 --> 00:18:37.040
evaluating ourselves as IT and
evaluating whether we

314
00:18:37.040 --> 00:18:42.220
are delivering value to the business
that's about improving quality.

315
00:18:42.220 --> 00:18:46.350
But it's really about
ensuring that we remain

316
00:18:46.350 --> 00:18:48.050
aligned to the needs of the business.

317
00:18:49.400 --> 00:18:50.300
That's what we need to do.

318
00:18:51.330 --> 00:18:56.189
So improvement to the business, or
rather business benefits of bringing in IT

319
00:18:56.189 --> 00:19:01.210
service management, means that in
an organization, we've got a handle on IT.

320
00:19:01.210 --> 00:19:03.750
We know what IT is doing.

321
00:19:03.750 --> 00:19:07.490
And we are able to make better
decisions on our strategy,

322
00:19:07.490 --> 00:19:11.430
based on what IT can provide us
because we have faith in IT.

323
00:19:12.695 --> 00:19:16.330
If IT understand the organization,

324
00:19:16.330 --> 00:19:19.910
then the organization can be
more agile in the market place.

325
00:19:21.590 --> 00:19:24.900
Because again,
they have that trust with IT, but

326
00:19:24.900 --> 00:19:27.390
IT is also working for the business.

327
00:19:27.390 --> 00:19:29.620
IT is not a constraint,

328
00:19:29.620 --> 00:19:35.001
It means that because IT understands
what the business is trying to achieve,

329
00:19:35.001 --> 00:19:39.820
we can be efficient and
effective at providing efficient services.

330
00:19:39.820 --> 00:19:41.990
In other words,
improving their productivity.

331
00:19:43.460 --> 00:19:47.670
And again, having efficient and
effective methods and processes for

332
00:19:47.670 --> 00:19:52.620
managing our suppliers means that we
have rationalized sourcing as well.

333
00:19:53.710 --> 00:19:55.710
Because we're able to do it here in IT.

334
00:19:56.770 --> 00:20:01.308
We are able to the business,
with a structured framework,

335
00:20:01.308 --> 00:20:05.487
with efficient and
effective consistent processes,

336
00:20:05.487 --> 00:20:10.685
we are able to deliver competitive
advantage to the organization.

337
00:20:10.685 --> 00:20:15.662
And in IT, what that means for us is that
if we have got a structured, consistent,

338
00:20:15.662 --> 00:20:18.116
efficient, and effective framework,

339
00:20:18.116 --> 00:20:21.745
it means that we actually get
a reduction in support cause.

340
00:20:21.745 --> 00:20:24.005
It means that our resolution rates go up.

341
00:20:24.005 --> 00:20:26.135
It means that we can implement
more successful changes.

342
00:20:26.135 --> 00:20:29.105
And again,
we can make better sourcing decisions.

343
00:20:29.105 --> 00:20:34.730
And then when we say, I just wanna go
back to that more succesful changes,

344
00:20:34.730 --> 00:20:39.560
I also want to bring in the increased
volume of changes as well.

345
00:20:39.560 --> 00:20:43.700
Because if our processes are more
efficient and we have a consistent way

346
00:20:43.700 --> 00:20:48.130
of managing change, then actually we
can handle a higher volume of change.

347
00:20:49.440 --> 00:20:54.830
And something else that we do too with
consistency is bringing a common language.

348
00:20:56.420 --> 00:20:59.500
This is a huge, big benefit to IT.

349
00:20:59.500 --> 00:21:02.730
Because it means that
our IT teams are talking

350
00:21:02.730 --> 00:21:07.235
to each other in a common language,
but it also means that our IT

351
00:21:07.235 --> 00:21:12.860
teams are able to talk to all of
their suppliers in a common language.

352
00:21:12.860 --> 00:21:19.292
Because if I consider ITIL itself as
a service management framework then, let's

353
00:21:19.292 --> 00:21:25.830
just say that ITIL is the most globally
recognized service management framework.

354
00:21:25.830 --> 00:21:28.630
Well, I said globally, in the world.

355
00:21:28.630 --> 00:21:31.380
It's the most widespread
service management frame work.

356
00:21:31.380 --> 00:21:36.710
If you are a supplier, or a vendor,
and you are trying to bid for

357
00:21:36.710 --> 00:21:40.340
a particular contract say within the
government, anywhere around the world you

358
00:21:40.340 --> 00:21:44.320
have to demonstrate that you
are working to an ITIL framework.

359
00:21:44.320 --> 00:21:46.600
That you understand service management,
and

360
00:21:46.600 --> 00:21:49.740
that you are working to best practices.

361
00:21:49.740 --> 00:21:54.540
But actually you are therefore
able to demonstrate that

362
00:21:54.540 --> 00:21:58.800
you make best use of the tax payers
money that's being given to you.

363
00:21:58.800 --> 00:22:03.660
So there is actually a requirement if
you want to be a supplier to government,

364
00:22:03.660 --> 00:22:06.410
that you work to a best
practice framework.

365
00:22:07.660 --> 00:22:11.953
Well if that's a requirement then that
means that they're working in a certain

366
00:22:11.953 --> 00:22:15.360
way and they want to make sure
you're working in a certain way.

367
00:22:15.360 --> 00:22:19.481
So we're all using
the same common language,

368
00:22:19.481 --> 00:22:23.400
we all have exactly
the same way of working.

369
00:22:24.750 --> 00:22:30.590
Ultimately, efficiency leads to
higher customer satisfaction,

370
00:22:30.590 --> 00:22:33.030
that's what it is that we are aiming for.

371
00:22:34.980 --> 00:22:38.130
And so
why do we want to adopt ITIL itself, then?

372
00:22:38.130 --> 00:22:42.500
Well, ITIL is pretty much the same as
any other service management framework.

373
00:22:42.500 --> 00:22:47.845
But as I've said, ITIL is the most
globally recognized, should we say.

374
00:22:47.845 --> 00:22:51.481
And what you do with ITIL,
is you adopt it, and

375
00:22:51.481 --> 00:22:54.670
you adapt it to suit your organization.

376
00:22:54.670 --> 00:22:58.509
So, it will help you to
improve your overall quality,

377
00:22:58.509 --> 00:23:03.432
it will help you to control costs,
and it will help you to align service

378
00:23:03.432 --> 00:23:07.790
management to the business and
align IT to the organization.

379
00:23:07.790 --> 00:23:11.840
>> And Jo, at the beginning of the show
you mentioned tangible reasons, and

380
00:23:11.840 --> 00:23:15.320
that you'd give us some numbers,
so where are we at with that?

381
00:23:15.320 --> 00:23:16.940
>> Yeah, I did, yeah.

382
00:23:16.940 --> 00:23:20.230
But, right, well I'll just taking
a look at the time, actually.

383
00:23:20.230 --> 00:23:23.590
And so what I'm gonna do, is I'm gonna
leave you with a little bit of a teaser.

384
00:23:23.590 --> 00:23:25.470
So we're gonna come back in a part two,

385
00:23:25.470 --> 00:23:27.682
and we're gonna talk
about that in part two.

386
00:23:27.682 --> 00:23:31.400
>> Part two of ITIL Executive Overview.

387
00:23:31.400 --> 00:23:34.920
Benefits of Service Management, part two
coming your way, this has been part one.

388
00:23:34.920 --> 00:23:37.730
Make sure you watch everything in
the ITIL Executive Overview series,

389
00:23:37.730 --> 00:23:39.500
you're gonna be very glad that you did.

390
00:23:39.500 --> 00:23:42.870
And by the way, you'll also be in the
course library, where there's thousands of

391
00:23:42.870 --> 00:23:45.910
hours of additional content that's
there to help you be successful.

392
00:23:45.910 --> 00:23:47.320
So check that out as well.

393
00:23:47.320 --> 00:23:48.900
Well, what do you know about ITProTV.

394
00:23:48.900 --> 00:23:51.860
ITProTV is binge-worthy, thanks for
watching, I'm Zach Memos.

395
00:23:51.860 --> 00:23:52.376
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

396
00:23:52.376 --> 00:23:53.990
>> We will see you again very soon.

397
00:23:53.990 --> 00:23:59.510
[MUSIC]

398
00:23:59.510 --> 00:24:03.030
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: This 2-parter gives looks at the common complaints that businesses have with IT and the reasons for implementing an IT Service Management framework. In the 2nd episode we explore the numbers behind the benefits that have been reaslised by organisations of varying sizes globally.
episodes.title: Benefits of Service Management Part 2

episodes.description: An brief, very high-level, overview of the most globally recognised ITSM famework: ITIL.
episodes.title: ITIL Fundamentals

episodes.description: An brief, very high-level, overview of the most globally recognised ITSM famework: ITIL.
episodes.title: ITIL Fundamentals Part 2
